key_channel_insights.line_content: The OTA channel reflects higher prices for 43.5% of origin-destination pairs, with a 1.64% average price increase.
The MSE channel exhibited a 55.2% availability of fare offers aligning with the airline's website, indicating improved pricing consistency.
The GDS channel has 88% of prices higher than the airline's direct website, underscoring significant reliance on GDS for premium pricing.

conclusion.line_content: This report provides a high-level summary of the price discrepancies observed across different channels.  It is important to note that the data contains many nuances depending on various factors such as market conditions, booking windows, and the competitive landscape. Understanding these subtleties can be critical in optimizing pricing strategies and ensuring competitive positioning.

As part of our 'PriceEye' solution, we are developing an intuitive dashboard designed to help your airline's analysts drill down into this data. This tool will allow you to uncover and focus on critical actionable insights, enabling your team to make data-driven decisions with confidence.

We are here to support you in leveraging these insights to enhance your revenue management and distribution strategies. Please don't hesitate to connect with our team for more information about how PriceEye can assist you in achieving your business objectives.

ota_highlights.line_content: The OTA channel shows higher prices for 43.5% of origin-destination pairs last week, accompanied by an average price increase of 1.64%.
Website offers were not found on OTA channel for 56.2% of analyzed routes last week, indicating limited availability.
Only 0.3% of routes presented a lower price through the OTA channel compared to the airline's website, emphasizing the rarity of competitive pricing.

ota_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: 43.5% of routes had higher prices on the OTA channel compared to the airline's website, with consistent increases observed for the past two weeks.
Pricing was identical across the OTA and airline's site for less than 1% of options, indicating a lack of parity.

ota_summary_by_region.line_content: Price discrepancies by region show that over 40% of routes from Europe had higher costs on the OTA channel, correlating with overall trends.

ota_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: Domestic routes exhibit higher OTA pricing at 44.3%, while a smaller percentage of 40.9% pertains to international routes showing the same trend.

ota_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: OTA prices for close-in bookings were higher for 43.9% of itineraries, a pattern consistent over the last month.

mse_highlights.line_content: The MSE channel reported a 55.2% availability of fare offers that aligned with the airline's website in the last week, indicating solid consistency in pricing.
In the last week, only 0.4% of the offerings were priced higher on the MSE channel, suggesting minimal price discrepancies.
Short haul itineraries showed a measurable 12.2% decline in prices via the MSE channel compared to the airline's site, enhancing competitive positioning in this segment.

mse_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: Last week, 57.9% of the offerings were not found on the MSE channel, a higher rate compared to previous periods.
The percentage of same prices between the MSE channel and the airline website remained stable, at approximately 29.3% over the last week.

mse_summary_by_region.line_content: In the domestic market, 59.2% of the fares were unavailable via MSE, which could indicate an opportunity for expanded offerings.
Across short haul routes, the MSE provided a more favorable pricing option 12.2% of the time, compared to the airline's website.

mse_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: For Turkey, the MSE channel had a 35.9% match with the airline's prices, underlining competitive fare distribution.
For non-Turkish points of origin, only 7.2% of prices matched the website, indicating a potential gap in offer integration.

mse_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: The MSE offered lower prices 12.2% of the time for close-in bookings, promoting preferred pricing for last-minute travelers.
There was a notable 12.5% increase in fare offers for far-out bookings on the MSE channel compared to previous periods, enhancing future demand capture.

gds_highlights.line_content: In the latest week, 88% of the GDS prices were higher than the airline's direct website, indicating a significant reliance on GDS for higher-priced tickets.
There was little change in the price comparison status, with 0% of fares the same as those on the airline's website over the last week.
Only 0.01% of GDS fares were found to be lower than the airline's website, suggesting minimal competitive pricing through the GDS channel.

gds_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: In the latest week, GDS listings showed a 'higher' status 88% of the time compared to the airline's website, a trend persisting over the past two periods.
The proportion of the same price status remained at zero across all segments for the latest week, indicating limited overlap with website prices.

gds_summary_by_region.line_content: All regions reported GDS prices predominantly higher than the website, with no findings of lower pricing instances.

gds_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: Fares from Turkey consistently showed GDS prices higher, with no recorded lower prices, highlighting a lack of competitive pricing.
Non-Turkish origins also predominantly exhibited higher GDS pricing, again reflecting a consistent pricing strategy across both origin categories.

gds_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: Close-in bookings were overwhelmingly higher in GDS prices, indicating a trend in charge disparities for last-minute travelers.
The far-out booking window also reported predominantly higher GDS prices, underscoring a widespread pricing strategy.
